clinical_study.brief_title: Adductor Canal Block in Outpatient Clinic for Pain Control After Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Adductor Canal Block in Outpatient Clinic

brief_summary.textblock: Single-shot Adductor Canal Block in the outpatient clinic is safe, significantly decreased pain and analgesic consumption and may enhance the rehabilitation program

detailed_description.textblock: The ACB in the outpatient clinic is safe and can minimize postoperative pain. The primary goal of this research was to see how ACB affected the Visual Analog Score (VAS) pain score during the rehabilitation as opposed to controls. The secondary goal was to determine how much analgesic (etoricoxibe) was consumed on a daily basis.

primary_outcome.description: A VAS scale was used to assess pain severity, with 0 indicating no pain and 10 indicating extreme pain

secondary_outcome.description: determine how much analgesic (etoricoxibe) was consumed on a daily basis.

arm_group.arm_group_label: pain management post total knee arthroplasty with analgetic oral
arm_group.description: Patients in control group were given analgesic (etoricoxibe) on a daily basis, with the option to increase the dose if pain persisted, up to a maximum of 120 mg per day.

arm_group.arm_group_label: pain management post total knee arthroplasty with adductor canal block
arm_group.description: On postoperative day 14 (POD 14), the ACB was performed for ACB group

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Indonesian or Javanese-speaking adults
- After perfomed total knee replacement
- American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I-III
- body mass index (BMI) of 18-40 kg/m2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Declined to complete the study
- Unable to cooperate
- had an allergic reaction to any of the drugs
- abusing alcohol or drugs
